required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Safety and Efficacy Trial for Alpha-Beta Depleted T-Cell Infusions Post Haplo Transplant
clinical_study.official_title: Phase I/II Study of Post-transplant Alpha-beta Depleted T-cell Infusion Following Haploidentical Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation Using Post-Transplant Cyclophosphamide

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine the safety and efficacy of post-transplant cyclophosphamide and a post-transplant infusion of donor cells, that have been specially processed to remove alpha beta t-cells, in patients undergoing a haploidentical allogeneic stem cell transplant to help reduce the risk of relapse without increasing the risk of graft-versus-host disease.

detailed_description.textblock: Transplant patients participating in this clinical trial will receive one of 3 standard pre-transplant chemotherapy preparative regimens as appropriate for their specific disease. They will then receive a standard non-manipulated donor stem cell infusion on transplant day (day 0) followed by cyclophosphamide (days +3 and +4) and an alpha-beta t-cell reduced donor stem cell infusion on day +7.

primary_outcome.description: Progression-free survival will be calculated as time lapsed from transplant to either any death or disease relapse or progression.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Within the first 100 days after transplant.
From day +101 after transplant through one year.

arm_group.description: Post-transplant alpha-beta depleted T-cell infusion after post-transplant cyclophosphamide.

intervention.intervention_name: Alpha-beta depleted T-cell infusion after post-transplant cyclophosphamide.
intervention.description: Post-transplant alpha-beta depleted T-cell infusion after post-transplant cyclophosphamide.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Neoplastic hematological disorder with indication of allogeneic transplant
- No available suitable HLA-matched donor
- Adequate cardiac, pulmonary, renal, and hepatic function
- Karnofsky performance status score greater than or equal to 70%
Exclusion Criteria:
- Medication non-compliance
- No appropriate caregiver identified
- Uncontrolled medical or psychiatric disorder
- Active central nervous system (CNS) neoplastic involvement
- Known allergy to Dimethyl Sulfoxide
- HIV1 or HIV2 positive
- Pregnant or breastfeeding

facility.name: UAB Medical Center (University of Alabama at Birmingham)

link.description: Click here for more information about the Bone Marrow Transplantation and Cell Therapy Program at the University of Alabama at Birmingham.
